University of Guelph.; Department of Integrative Biology. College of Biological Science. University of Guelph.; Department of Integrative Biology. College of Biological Science. University of Guelph.; Department of Integrative Biology. College of Biological Science. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; Earth and Environmental Sciences; Salvelinus fontinalis; freshwater conservation; environmental DNA; target qPCR detection; indicator species; aquatic biodiversity
Objectives: This data is the result of targeted brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) detection from two creeks in Southwestern Ontario: Hanlon Creek in Guelph ON, and 12-Mile Creek near Pelham ON. The purpose of this data was to determine whether or not brook trout were occupying the two creeks during the time of sampling. This dataset contains the raw qPCR files obtained from the MIC thermocycler as well as the formatted data set, metadata including electrofishing results, and R scripts used for analysis.

Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; Agriculture; Prices; deferred; grain; prices; exchange; corn; soybean; feed futures; low; high; barley; wheat; currency; crop; cash
Objectives: This dataset contains Ontario corn prices collected by University of Guelph, Ridgetown Campus. Authors: Santos, Rafael M.
Affiliations: School of Engineering. College of Engineering and Physical Sciences. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; Engineering; Agroindustry; Market research; Fertilizer industry; carbon-sequestering; agriculture; environment; fertilizer; slow release fertilizer; market; interviews; surveys

Title: Photodiaries of manomin on the Upper Winnipeg River
Authors: Bradford, Andrea; Luby, Brittany; Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation
Affiliations: School of Engineering. College of Engineering and Physical Sciences. University of Guelph.; Department of History. College of Arts. University of Guelph.; NA
Keywords: Other; Indigenous agriculture; Indigenous foodways; manomin; photodiary; crop monitoring; Zizania palustris
Objectives: This image collection or photodiary was intended to document the extent and density of manomin growth at each visible life stage at sites selected by Elders from Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation. It was also intended to monitor the extent and density of invasive hybrid cattail, a species that competes with the manomin for territory. Manomin is commonly and inaccurately known as "wild rice" in English. Its Latin name is Zizania palustris.
Citation: NA
Funder: Royal Bank of Canada Ontario Resource Field Program; George Weston Ltd. Seeding Food Innovation Grant
DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - The Manomin Research Project

Title: Culturally Sensitive Field Protocol: The Manomin Project
Authors: Luby, Brittany; Bradford, Andrea; Mehltretter, Samantha; Luby, Allan; Wagamese, Archie; Henry, Barry; Henry, Clarence; Strong, Danny; Henry, John; Klein, Josephine; Kabestra, Larry; Greene, Terry; Jourdain, Theresa; Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation
Affiliations: Department of History. College of Arts. University of Guelph.; School of Engineering. College of Engineering and Physical Sciences. University of Guelph.; School of Engineering. College of Engineering and Physical Sciences. University of Guelph.; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA; NA
Keywords: Other; Indigenous agriculture; Indigenous foodways; manomin; crop monitoring; Zizania palustris; field protocol
Objectives: This field protocol was developed to guide respectful, ethical and culturally sensitive research activities in the project, Intensifying manomin (Zizania palustris) growth in environments altered by colonial settlement in ways that are responsive to Anishinaabe knowledge and values. The Manomin Project, funded by George Weston Ltd., aims to integrate environmental data retrieved by University of Guelph (UofG) researchers with cultural and ecological knowledge from Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation with the objective of restoring Manomin (commonly known in English as “wild rice”) on the Upper Winnipeg River. At present, the Research Ethics Board at U of G does not recognize Manomin as a spirit being like the Anishinabeg do. Due to differences in cultural beliefs and ways of knowing, it was essential to the project that a culturally sensitive field protocol be developed to sustain a healthy and respectful relationship between U of G researchers, Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation (NAN), and Manomin (a non-human collaborator).
Citation: Luby, B.; Mehltretter, S.; Flewelling, R.; Lehman, M.; Goldhar, G.; Pattrick, E.; Mariotti, J.; Bradford, A.; Niisaachewan Anishinaabe Nation. Beyond Institutional Ethics: Anishinaabe Worldviews and the Development of a Culturally Sensitive Field Protocol for Aquatic Plant Research. Water 2021, 13, 709. https://doi.org/10.3390/w13050709
DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - The Manomin Research Project

Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This data schema is used for recording and managing disease diagnosis and treatment events for beef cattle. Title: ODRC data schema: Feed aggregation
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; feed intake; Insentec; heifer
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting aggregated daily feed intakes data for animals fed at the maternity & tie stalls and from Insentec bins. Daily intakes for Insentec data is the sum of all positive intakes per animal per day using data from the Insentec (FR) table (Insentec data from VR files with end weight and intake fixed). Fixing strategy: If start weight of the following visit is equal (cow didn't eat) or smaller than the current visit's start weight (cow ate) and the following visit's start weight is different than the current visit's end weight, then the current visit's end weight is replaced with the start weight of the following visit. These conditions are applied with data grouped by date and bin and sorted ascending by start time. Limitation: Because data is grouped by date, if the last visit of a day registered an incorrect weight to a bin, it will not be corrected with the first visit of the following day of such bin. Additionally, if the start weight of the following visit is greater than the start weight of the current visit, then nothing is done since supplement/more feed could have been added to the bin between visits or the scale was really broken. Further inspection to the data is recommended. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.
Citation: NA
DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - Agri-food Data Canada - Ontario Dairy Research Centre

Title: ODRC data schema: Feed carts
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; feed intake; Super Data Ranger; feed orts
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting Feed Intake data from animals housed at the Tie Stall & Maternity. Feed is offered in the morning with a Super Data Ranger which records the exact amount of feed dropped from equipment to the individual animal. Left-over feed (orts) is manually shoveled into the Orts Cart on the following morning before new feed is offered to the animal. Because of the way the scale on the Orts Cart is setup, orts are recorded as negative values, e.g. an orts value of -10.5 means the animal had 10.5 Kg of orts in front of her in the morning. Total intake is calculated only when both amounts are available. If there is no value for feed offered or orts, such data is missing. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.

Title: ODRC data schema: Insentec feed intake data (FR)
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; Insentec; feed intake; feed bin weight
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting Insentec data from VR files with end weight and intake fixed. Assumption: The start weight of the following visit is more accurate than the end weight of the current visit since the scale on the bin had more time to get a more stabilized weight before the next cow's visit. Fixing strategy: If the start weight of following visit is equal (cow didn't eat) or smaller than the current visit's start weight (cow ate) and the following visit's start weight is different than the current visit's end weight, then the current visit's end weight is replaced with the start weight of the following visit. These conditions are applied with data grouped by date and bin and sorted ascending by start time. Limitation: Because data is grouped by date, if the last visit of a day registered an incorrect weight to a bin, it will not be corrected with the first visit of the following day of such bin. Additionally if the start weight of the following visit is greater than the start weight of the current visit, then nothing is done since supplement/more feed could have been added to the bin between visits or the scale was really broken. Further inspection into the data is recommended. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.
Citation: NA
DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - Agri-food Data Canada - Ontario Dairy Research Centre

Title: ODRC data schema: Feed intake during milking
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; feed intake; milking; voluntary milking system; VMS
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting data on feed pellets dispensed to cows at the Voluntary Milking System (VMS) during milking. There is no scale to weigh the actual amount of feed consumed. Each record is the total amount (kg) of feed pellets dispensed hourly - e.g. hour = 14:00:00 and feed_dispensed = 1.5, therefore this cow ate 1.5 kg of feed from 1 pm to 2 pm. If a cow started milking at 03:55:00 and finished at 04:05:00 there will be two records for that session, one for the amount dispensed until 4 am and another for the amount dispensed until 5 am. Milking start and end times are not necessarily the same times for feeding, i.e. a cow could start milking at 03:55:00 but only start eating at 04:01:00, therefore she would only have one record for that session to reflect the amount she ate until 5 am. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.

DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - Agri-food Data Canada - Ontario Dairy Research Centre

Title: ODRC data schema: Voluntary milking system (VMS) data
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; voluntary milking system; VMS; days in milk; milking duration; lactation; milk yield
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting data from the Voluntary Milking System (VMS). This schema is used for organizing and analyzing data related to milking sessions of dairy cattle. This schema includes various metrics related to milk production and milking efficiency during Voluntary Milking System (VMS) milkings. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.

Title: ODRC data schema: Animal activity sensor data
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; activity change; AllFlex sensor
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is designed for the collection and representation of activity sensor data from the Allflex/Heatime System (SCR) used in dairy cattle management. The Allflex/Heatime (SCR) System is an advanced livestock monitoring solution designed specifically for dairy cattle. It utilizes a combination of wearable collars and software to collect and analyze data related to animal health, behavior, and productivity. Features of this system include: Activity monitoring, rumination tracking, heat detection, and health alerts. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.

DataverseName: Agri-environmental Research Data - Agri-food Data Canada - Ontario Dairy Research Centre

Title: ODRC data schema: Lactating housing ventilation data
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; ventilation; lactation housing; carbon dioxide; humidity; temperature; windspeed
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is designed for the standardized collection of ventilation data recorded every 15 minutes from sensors spread across the Lactating Housing facilities. It is applicable to all datasets aimed at monitoring environmental conditions affecting dairy cattle in the Lactating Housing Facilities. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.

Title: ODRC data schema: Voluntary milking system (VMS) action data
Authors: Brock, Erica; Alcantara, Lucas; Husiny, Jaber; Edwards, Michelle; Huitema, Carly
Affiliations: Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Department of Plant Agriculture. Ontario Agricultural College. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.; Office of Research. University of Guelph.
Keywords: Agricultural Sciences; dairy cattle; heifer; voluntary milking system; VMS; action; milking; milking rejected; release unmilked
Objectives: This is a data schema created using Agri-food Data Canada's Semantic Engine . Data schemas describe data that are collected on an ongoing basis from research centres, and provide add-on documentation that enhances the value of raw data. This schema is applicable to all datasets collecting data on action taken by the Voluntary Milking System (VMS) upon a cow's entry. When a cow enters the Voluntary Milking System (VMS), the system can either accept the cow for milking, reject the cow for milking, or release the cow unmilked. Data described in this schema is sample data, to request access to the related data, please visit the Ontario Dairy Research Centre Data Portal.
